explanation.short: Normally-open means the valve is open with no control signal applied - it fails to the open position.
explanation.detailed: NO/NC refers to valve position without control signal (spring position or de-energized state). NO (normally open): valve is open at 0% signal, closes as signal increases. NC (normally closed): valve is closed at 0% signal, opens as signal increases. Selection depends on fail-safe requirements: heating valves often NO (fail open for freeze protection); cooling valves often NC (fail closed to prevent overcooling).

questions.question: What happens if a control valve is oversized for the application?

choices.b: Poor control - small valve movements cause large flow changes, leading to hunting

explanation.short: Oversized valves provide poor control because small position changes cause large flow changes, making stable control difficult.
explanation.detailed: Valve sizing uses Cv (flow coefficient) to match valve capacity to required flow and pressure drop. Oversized valve: operates mostly near closed position; small movements cause large flow changes; control is erratic or hunts. Undersized valve: can't pass enough flow; operates wide open; no control authority. Proper sizing: valve operates in 20-80% range at design conditions. Allow adequate pressure drop across valve (typically 25-50% of coil drop).

questions.question: What is the function of a three-way mixing valve in a hydronic system?

choices.b: Blend supply and return water to control temperature to the load

explanation.short: Three-way mixing valves blend hot supply water with cooler return water to achieve the desired supply temperature to the load.
explanation.detailed: Three-way valves have three ports: A (typically hot supply), B (typically return/bypass), and AB (mixed outlet). As the valve modulates, it changes the proportion of A and B in the AB outlet. Mixing application: control supply temperature to a zone while maintaining constant flow. Diverting application: direct flow to load or bypass. Three-way valves maintain constant flow through the system regardless of valve position.

questions.question: How does a two-way control valve differ from a three-way valve?

choices.b: Two-way throttles flow through the coil; three-way maintains constant flow by bypassing

explanation.short: Two-way valves throttle flow through the coil, varying system flow. Three-way valves maintain constant flow by mixing or diverting.
explanation.detailed: Two-way valves: modulate flow through the load (coil). As valve closes, flow decreases. System flow varies with valve position. Works with variable-speed pumping. Three-way valves: maintain constant flow through the system by mixing supply with bypass (or diverting flow to bypass). Better for constant-flow systems. Two-way valves are more common in modern variable-flow systems for energy efficiency.

questions.question: Why are equal percentage valve characteristics often used for HVAC coil control?

choices.b: Provides more linear heat transfer control because coil output is non-linear with flow

explanation.short: Equal percentage valves compensate for non-linear coil heat transfer, resulting in more linear overall temperature control.
explanation.detailed: Coil heat output is non-linear with flow - most heat transfer occurs in the first 50% of flow. A linear valve would give non-linear temperature control (large temp change at low flow, little change at high flow). Equal percentage valves have the opposite characteristic - small flow change at low openings, large at high. The combination of equal percentage valve with non-linear coil results in more linear temperature control.

questions.question: How are safety devices typically wired in HVAC control circuits?

choices.a: In parallel so one can bypass another
choices.b: In series so any safety opening breaks the circuit

explanation.short: Safeties are wired in series so that any single safety device opening will break the control circuit and stop equipment.
explanation.detailed: Safety devices (high/low pressure switches, limit switches, flow switches, flame rollout) are wired in series in the control circuit. If any one opens, the circuit breaks and equipment stops. This ensures any single safety condition shuts down the system. Never bypass safeties - they protect equipment and people. Some safeties are auto-reset; others are manual-reset to force acknowledgment and diagnosis before restart.

questions.question: Why do some safety switches require manual reset?

choices.b: To ensure the condition is investigated before equipment restarts

explanation.short: Manual reset forces investigation of the safety condition before restart, preventing repeated cycling on a dangerous condition.
explanation.detailed: Manual reset safeties (like rollout switches and some high limits) require physical button press or power cycle to reset. Purpose: force someone to acknowledge the safety trip and investigate the cause before restarting. Auto-reset safeties (like many pressure switches) reset automatically when the condition clears - acceptable for transient conditions but not for serious safety events that indicate underlying problems.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference manual vs auto reset safeties

questions.question: What is compressor outdoor lockout?

choices.b: Preventing compressor operation when outdoor temperature is too low for safe operation

explanation.short: Outdoor lockout prevents compressor operation below a minimum outdoor temperature to protect equipment and ensure oil return.
explanation.detailed: Air conditioning compressors shouldn't operate below certain outdoor temperatures (typically 55-65°F for standard AC, lower for heat pumps). Reasons: oil migration and return issues at low ambient; potential liquid slugging; inefficient operation. Controls can lock out cooling based on outdoor sensor. Heat pump lockout is lower (often 0°F or below with proper controls). Some systems have low-ambient kits to allow cold-weather operation.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a deadband between heating and cooling setpoints?

choices.b: Prevent simultaneous heating and cooling by creating a temperature gap

explanation.short: Deadband is the temperature gap between heating and cooling setpoints that prevents both from operating simultaneously.
explanation.detailed: Deadband prevents energy waste from fighting between heating and cooling. Example: if heating setpoint is 70°F and cooling setpoint is 75°F, the 5°F deadband means neither operates between 70-75°F. ASHRAE 90.1 requires minimum 5°F deadband (2.8°C). Thermostats typically enforce minimum separation. Without deadband, systems could heat and cool simultaneously, wasting energy. Humidity control may require reducing deadband in some applications.

questions.question: What is morning warmup mode in commercial HVAC?

choices.b: Running heating with minimum outdoor air to quickly bring building to temperature before occupancy

explanation.short: Morning warmup runs heating with outdoor air dampers closed/minimized to quickly recover from night setback before occupants arrive.
explanation.detailed: After night setback, buildings need to return to comfort temperature before occupancy. Morning warmup mode: closes outdoor air damper to minimum position; runs heating at full capacity; uses recirculated air only. This heats the building faster without the penalty of conditioning cold outdoor air. Once temperature is near setpoint or occupancy begins, system transitions to normal occupied mode with required ventilation.

questions.question: What is night purge or night flush cooling?

choices.b: Using cool nighttime outdoor air to pre-cool the building mass, reducing next-day cooling load

explanation.short: Night purge uses cool nighttime outdoor air to flush heat from the building mass, reducing cooling needs the following day.
explanation.detailed: In climates with cool nights and warm days, buildings with thermal mass (concrete, masonry) can benefit from night flush. Operation: when outdoor temp drops sufficiently below indoor temp, fans run with 100% outdoor air to cool the building structure. The cooled mass then absorbs heat during the next day, reducing or delaying mechanical cooling needs. Requires suitable climate (cool dry nights) and building construction.

questions.question: During unoccupied mode, what typically happens to ventilation in commercial buildings?

choices.b: Reduces to minimum or zero since no occupants need fresh air

explanation.short: Unoccupied mode reduces or eliminates outdoor air ventilation since no occupants require fresh air.
explanation.detailed: Ventilation requirements (ASHRAE 62.1) are based on occupancy. When unoccupied, the ventilation requirement is minimal or zero. Unoccupied mode: closes outdoor air dampers (or minimum for building pressurization); sets back temperature; may shut down or cycle equipment. Saves significant energy by not conditioning unnecessary outdoor air. Transitions back to occupied mode before occupancy for warmup/cooldown and ventilation.

questions.question: What is an occupant override in building automation?

choices.b: Temporary extension of occupied mode after normal hours, typically via button or phone

explanation.short: Override allows occupants to temporarily extend occupied conditioning after normal hours, usually for a preset duration.
explanation.detailed: When occupants work late, they need conditioning beyond scheduled hours. Override (via wall button, phone, or web interface) temporarily extends occupied mode - typically 1-4 hours. After the override period, system returns to unoccupied setback. Prevents scheduling everyone for late hours due to occasional needs. Some systems charge tenants for override usage. Limits on override duration prevent energy waste.

questions.question: What is demand limiting in building energy management?

choices.b: Shedding or cycling loads to prevent peak electrical demand from exceeding a target

explanation.short: Demand limiting sheds or cycles electrical loads to keep peak demand below a target, reducing demand charges on utility bills.
explanation.detailed: Utilities charge for both energy usage (kWh) and peak demand (kW) - the highest 15-minute average draw. Demand charges can be 30-50% of commercial electric bills. Demand limiting monitors real-time demand and sheds loads when approaching the target: cycles HVAC units off temporarily; delays equipment starts; dims lighting. Loads are prioritized - less critical loads shed first. Sophisticated systems predict demand and act proactively.

questions.question: What is duty cycling in HVAC control?

choices.b: Periodically shutting off equipment for short intervals during low-load conditions

explanation.short: Duty cycling periodically shuts off equipment (e.g., 10 minutes per hour) during low-load periods to save energy.
explanation.detailed: During mild conditions when loads are low, equipment may run continuously at minimum capacity, wasting energy. Duty cycling sheds equipment for portions of each hour (e.g., 50 minutes on, 10 minutes off). Building thermal mass carries through the off period. Sophisticated controls monitor zone temperatures and adjust cycling to maintain comfort. Often used for RTUs in mild weather or as part of demand limiting.

questions.question: What is lead-lag control for multiple pieces of equipment?

choices.b: Alternating which unit operates first to equalize run time and wear

explanation.short: Lead-lag alternates which equipment starts first across multiple units, equalizing run hours and wear.
explanation.detailed: When multiple identical units serve a load (pumps, chillers, boilers), one could run much more than others, causing uneven wear. Lead-lag control rotates which unit is 'lead' (first to start). Rotation can be: time-based (weekly); event-based (each start); or run-hour based (unit with fewest hours leads). Equalizes maintenance needs and extends overall system life. Manual override allows technician selection.

questions.question: When is an enthalpy-based economizer better than a dry-bulb economizer?

choices.b: In humid climates where outdoor air may be cool but too humid for free cooling

explanation.short: Enthalpy economizers compare total heat content including humidity, preventing use of cool but humid outdoor air that would increase cooling load.
explanation.detailed: Dry-bulb economizers only consider temperature - they might bring in 65°F air that's 90% RH, adding latent load. Enthalpy economizers compare total heat content (sensible + latent) of outdoor and return air. They prevent economizing when outdoor air is cool but humid (high enthalpy). Better for humid climates (Southeast, coastal areas). Dry climates can use simpler dry-bulb control since humidity is rarely an issue.

questions.question: What is a DOAS in commercial HVAC?

choices.b: Dedicated Outdoor Air System - a unit that handles all ventilation air separately

explanation.short: A Dedicated Outdoor Air System (DOAS) provides all required ventilation air, conditioned separately from recirculated air.
explanation.detailed: DOAS units condition 100% outdoor air to neutral or near-neutral conditions and deliver it to zones. Benefits: decouples ventilation from zone conditioning; enables energy recovery on exhaust; consistent ventilation regardless of zone loads; works well with terminal systems (VRF, fan coils). The DOAS handles latent load from outdoor air; zone units handle sensible loads only. Growing in popularity for IAQ and energy efficiency.

questions.question: Why is differential pressure control used in variable-flow chilled water systems?

choices.b: To maintain minimum pressure across valves as flow varies, ensuring control valve authority

explanation.short: DP control maintains adequate pressure across control valves as system flow varies, preserving valve control authority.
explanation.detailed: Variable-flow systems modulate pump speed based on demand. As valves close, pressure increases; pump slows to maintain setpoint. DP sensor location is critical - typically across the hydraulically most remote coil. This ensures adequate pressure is always available for control valves to modulate properly. Without DP control, valves near the pump might see excess pressure while remote valves starve. Typical setpoint: 5-15 psid.

questions.question: How is duct static pressure typically controlled in a VAV system?

choices.b: VFD modulates fan speed to maintain static pressure setpoint in the duct

explanation.short: VAV supply fans use VFDs that modulate speed to maintain duct static pressure as VAV box dampers open and close.
explanation.detailed: As VAV box dampers close (zones satisfied), duct pressure rises. A duct static pressure sensor (typically at 2/3 duct length) sends signal to VFD, which slows the fan to maintain setpoint (typically 1.0-2.0 in. w.c.). As dampers open (zones call), pressure drops and fan speeds up. This matches fan energy to actual demand - major energy savings vs. constant volume. Static pressure reset can further optimize by lowering setpoint when boxes are satisfied.

questions.question: What does mixed air temperature control accomplish in an air handler?

choices.b: Modulates outdoor and return air dampers to achieve desired mixed air temperature

explanation.short: Mixed air temperature control modulates the ratio of outdoor to return air to achieve the desired mixed air temperature entering the coil.
explanation.detailed: Mixed air temperature is the blend of outdoor and return air before the coil. Control modulates OA/RA dampers: more outdoor air when it's cooler than return (economizing); minimum outdoor air when conditioning is needed. Mixed air setpoint is typically supply air setpoint minus the expected coil temperature drop. Maintains desired coil entering conditions. Also implements minimum ventilation requirements.

questions.question: What is supply air temperature reset?

choices.b: Raising supply air temperature when cooling load is low to save energy

explanation.short: SAT reset raises the supply air temperature setpoint when cooling load is low, reducing compressor energy and improving humidity control.
explanation.detailed: During low cooling load, maintaining design SAT (typically 55°F) wastes energy - zones quickly satisfy and equipment cycles. Reset strategy: raise SAT when most zones are satisfied; lower SAT when zones can't maintain setpoint. Benefits: reduced compressor energy, longer run times, better dehumidification. Reset range typically 55-65°F. Implemented via zone feedback or outdoor air temperature. Required by ASHRAE 90.1 for VAV systems.

questions.question: Why is proper startup sequence important for chilled water systems?

choices.b: Ensures pumps establish flow before chiller operates, preventing freeze-up or damage

explanation.short: Proper sequence ensures water flow is established and proven before chillers start, protecting equipment from freeze-up or damage.
explanation.detailed: Chilled water system startup sequence: (1) Open isolation valves; (2) Start condenser water pump, prove flow; (3) Start chilled water pump, prove flow; (4) Allow chiller to start. If chiller runs without flow, evaporator can freeze (water side) or overheat (refrigerant side). Flow switches provide proof. Shutdown is reverse order. Interlocks prevent out-of-sequence operation. Similar principles apply to boilers and cooling towers.

questions.question: What should happen to HVAC controls after power is restored following an outage?

choices.b: Staggered restart to prevent electrical surge and equipment damage

explanation.short: Controls should stagger equipment restarts after power restoration to prevent electrical surge and equipment damage.
explanation.detailed: Simultaneous restart after power restoration causes: massive inrush current (may trip breakers); voltage dip affecting sensitive equipment; mechanical stress from uncontrolled starts. Controls should: delay restarts by varied amounts; verify proper sequence (pumps before chillers); allow compressor anti-short-cycle timers to expire. Some systems require manual restart for safety. BAS programs should include power failure recovery logic.

questions.question: When is a remote temperature sensor used with a thermostat?

choices.b: When the thermostat location doesn't represent the controlled space temperature

explanation.short: Remote sensors control from a different location than the thermostat, useful when thermostat is poorly located or for averaging.
explanation.detailed: Sometimes thermostat location is dictated by wiring or aesthetics but doesn't represent room conditions (near door, in cabinet, etc.). Remote sensors mount where temperature is more representative and connect to the thermostat. Smart thermostats may have wireless remote sensors for multi-room averaging or priority room control. Some commercial systems use duct-mounted sensors for discharge air control rather than wall sensors.

questions.question: What information does a power monitor provide for HVAC equipment?

choices.b: Voltage, current, power factor, and kW/kWh for energy analysis and diagnostics

explanation.short: Power monitors measure electrical parameters including voltage, current, power factor, and energy consumption for analysis and diagnostics.
explanation.detailed: Power monitors (energy meters, power meters) measure: voltage; current; power factor; kW (instantaneous power); kWh (energy consumption); and sometimes harmonics. Uses: energy submetering for cost allocation; trending for optimization; diagnostics (high current indicates problems); demand monitoring; verifying VFD savings. Connected to BAS via Modbus, BACnet, or pulse outputs. Essential for energy management.

questions.question: What is automated fault detection and diagnostics (AFDD)?

choices.b: Software that analyzes system data to automatically identify equipment problems and inefficiencies

explanation.short: AFDD software analyzes operating data using rules or algorithms to automatically detect faults and diagnose problems.
explanation.detailed: AFDD systems use BAS data to detect problems humans might miss. Methods: rule-based (if outdoor damper reads open when OA temp equals mixed air temp = damper stuck); model-based (comparing actual performance to expected); statistical (detecting anomalies from historical patterns). Identifies: stuck dampers, failed sensors, simultaneous heating/cooling, scheduling errors, etc. Reduces energy waste and prevents equipment failures.

questions.question: What is a BAS points list?

choices.b: Documentation of all sensors, outputs, and software points with addresses and descriptions

explanation.short: A points list documents every BAS point including name, description, type, range, address, and engineering units.
explanation.detailed: The points list is a comprehensive database of all BAS points. Includes: point name (standardized naming convention); description; type (AI, AO, DI, DO, calculated); engineering units; range; controller address; alarm limits; and associated equipment. Used for: programming, troubleshooting, documentation, and training. Should be maintained throughout building life. Often in spreadsheet or database format. Part of project closeout documents.

questions.question: What are BAS graphics used for?

choices.b: Visual representation of system status, setpoints, and controls for operators

explanation.short: BAS graphics provide visual displays of equipment status, temperatures, setpoints, and controls for monitoring and operation.
explanation.detailed: Graphics are the operator interface to the BAS. They show: equipment diagrams with live status; sensor values displayed at their locations; control setpoints; alarm status; command buttons for manual control. Hierarchy typically includes: site overview, building overview, floor plans, and equipment detail pages. Good graphics make the system intuitive to operate. Should follow standards for consistency.

questions.question: What is a typical BAS network architecture?

choices.b: Hierarchical with field controllers, supervisory controllers, and operator workstation on IP backbone

explanation.short: Modern BAS uses hierarchical architecture: field controllers connect to supervisory controllers which connect to servers/workstations via IP network.
explanation.detailed: Typical BAS architecture: (1) Field level - controllers directly connected to sensors/actuators, communicate via MS/TP or other field bus; (2) Supervisory level - larger controllers managing multiple field controllers, often BACnet/IP; (3) Management level - servers, workstations, and integration with enterprise networks. IP backbone enables remote access, integration, and data exchange. Cybersecurity is increasingly important.

questions.question: What is BAS integration?

choices.b: Connecting different building systems (HVAC, lighting, fire, security) to share data and coordinate operation

explanation.short: BAS integration connects different building systems to share data, coordinate operation, and provide unified management.
explanation.detailed: Integration connects: HVAC control, lighting control, fire alarm, security/access, metering, vertical transport (elevators), and other systems. Benefits: coordinated occupancy response (lights, HVAC, access); fire system HVAC shutdown; central monitoring and alarming; energy optimization across systems. Protocols: BACnet, Modbus, LonWorks, or custom APIs. Integration requires careful point mapping and testing. Growing importance with smart building initiatives.

questions.question: Why is cybersecurity important for BAS systems?

choices.b: BAS connects to networks and can be entry point for attacks or target for disruption

explanation.short: BAS systems connected to networks can be attack vectors or targets, potentially disrupting operations or compromising building networks.
explanation.detailed: Networked BAS systems face cybersecurity risks: unauthorized access could disrupt building operations (disable HVAC, trigger alarms); BAS can be entry point to attack broader IT network (Target breach started through HVAC contractor); data theft (occupancy patterns, schedules). Mitigations: network segmentation, strong authentication, firmware updates, encrypted communications, monitoring for anomalies. NIST and DHS provide guidance.

questions.question: What documentation should be provided for a new BAS installation?

choices.b: As-built drawings, points list, sequence of operations, programming backup, and O&M manuals

explanation.short: Complete BAS documentation includes as-built drawings, points list, sequences, programming backups, network diagrams, and O&M manuals.
explanation.detailed: BAS closeout documentation should include: as-built control drawings; complete points list with addresses; sequence of operations (final version matching actual programming); programming backup files; network architecture diagrams; sensor calibration records; commissioning test results; O&M manuals for all components; training records; warranty information. Essential for ongoing operation and future modifications.
